Letter to London stock exchange ’ s management:

I am writing this letter to urge you to oppose the proposed offer made by the Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited (HKEX) for the following reasons:

1.
The current management of the HKEX has been unable to safeguard the interests of the public by allowing companies with dubious financial records to be listed.
The suspension of 0946.HK and 0246.HK shortly after the Initial Public Offerings(IPO) is one such example of how the HKEX has enabled, through lax controls, companies to gain access to public investors through fabricated financial statements and data (FIND SOUR CE!). The HKEX in failing to adequately manage the exchange has indirectly caused both investors and financial institutions to suffer huge financial losses. This type of behavior will only be replicated in London if the proposal to merge is accepted.

2.
Fraudulent reporting of financial data is an extremely common phenomena amongst Chinese companies. This can be seen in the cases of 8056.HK, 0773.HK, 0566-HK, 0279.HK, 2788.HK, 0189.HK, 8061.HK (FIND SOURCE!). This type of behavior has already raised concerns in the USA, which as a result has led to proposals by US Senator Marco Rubio to force Chinese companies that have gone public in New York to submit to audits and increased regulatory oversight or be delisted (FIND SOURCE!).
In merging with HKEX, the LSE will become another conduit for such companies to continue their charade at the expense of public interest, which could jeopardise the integrity of the entire European financial system.

3.
The politicisation of listed companies may also become more widespread as a result of the proposed merger.
There are currently over 100 companies listed on the HKEX which have been set up through the assistance of CCP backed committees in HKEX (FIND SOURCE!). This has drastically increased the power of the Mainland Chinese government to exert direct influence on the operation influence of these COMPANIES (FIND SOURCE!). Such influence will find its way into European companies if the merger occurs. It is unlikely such influence will have the interests and wellbeing of the European community as its key concern.

4.
The current CEO of the HKEX is Li Xiaojia, Charles who was a member of National Committee of the Chinese People’s Political Consultative Conference, the advisory member of Financial Experts Advisory Committee for Guangdong and the member of Consulting Committee of Qianhai Shenzhen-Hong Kong Modern Service Industry Cooperation Zone of Shenzhen (FIND SOURCE!). His status raises serious questions about whether he will be able to distinguish between his duties as the CEO of an institution designed to facilitate the raising of finance for companies, and his loyalties to Mainland Chinese government.

For all the abovementioned reasons, I sincerely urge the LSE to reject this proposed merger in order to safeguard the wellbeing of the international financial community and the continued prosperity brought about by genuine free market economies.
